bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Walt Whitman to William Sloane Kennedy, 27 August 1890
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839-1919, Library of Congress, Washington, DC.

body.p: Yr's rec'd—the Trans: comes regularly—thanks enclosed Logan Smith's letter Am feeling fairly—writing a little—presents of fruit (have just eaten two nice pears)—have just sold 50 copies folded in sheets (unbound) the big book (complete works) +3 each—wh—quite gets me up—was out last evn'g in wheel chair—plenty of rain here (rain last night)—get frequent word f'm Dr Bucke—all well—quite a good run of visitors talkers &c: street cries, hucksters, &c: some fine little children come letters lots some queer enough—occasionally one yet from former war-soldiers (one yesterday f'm California)—two or three days ago one f'm J A Symonds, f'm Switzerland—the grip has caught me again—have rather a bad bladder trouble interferes with my rest at night—inertia at times great—spirits bound up tho' soon as the pressure eases way—eyes going out plainly—want to finish & turn out this 2d annesc. while they serve altho' I guess there is nothing to it—Horace T is composing a piece abt me for the N E Magazine at their order I believe to come under the name of W W at date—we will see what it amt's too to —I am conciliatory ab't it—Horace is very good to me, ever faithful
Yes Let the Dutch article lie fallow a while—(but there's something special in it)—there I believe I have babbled enough
